awd_titl_txt: Tracing Gas from Bars to Nuclear Outflows: The Fermi Bubbles & Tilted Disk
awd_abstract_narration:
Dhanesh Krishnarao is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at Johns Hopkins University.  Krishnarao will track and study the flow of interstellar matter at high resolution near the center of the Milky Way (MW) galaxy using optical spectral lines.  He will observe large plasma outflows called Fermi Bubbles emanating from the MW nucleus, a structure of ionized gas called the “Tilted Disk” along the MW bar, and the Galactic analog of Low Ionization (Nuclear) Emission Regions or LI(N)ERs.  Results from this study will allow astronomers to understand how gas and radiation emerging from the center of a barred galaxy influence its formation and evolution, and they will shed light on the origin of LI(N)ERs.  For the education component of this project, Krishnarao will develop podcast-based audio courses to promote scientific inquiry in elementary and middle school students, including ones in local underserved communities.

Using the Wisconsin H-Alpha Mapper, this research project will produce the first ever continuous kinematic map of ionized gas in the Fermi Bubbles and the bar of the Milky Way. Combining existing emission-line and upcoming absorption-line observations in the fifth Sloan Digital Sky Survey, the project will develop a new statistical method to map the gas distribution at the disk-halo interface within the context of the bar and Fermi Bubbles. Lastly, the project will use 3D photoionization modeling with optical and UV spectra to develop a new understanding of LI(N)ERs within the MW bar.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award funded the postdoctoral fellow to advance research towards studying the environment surrounding the center of the Milky Way and inner parts of other galaxies using a combination of ground and space based observations across radio to ultraviolet wavelengths. This was accomplished using new and archival data of our own Galaxy, along with others, with added knowledge from simulations to model the behavior of gas and radiation. This ultimately led to two publications by the fellow as first author - one on resonances from bars in galaxies, and another on the gasseous cocoon around the Magellanic Clouds, a Magellanic Corona, which is strongly affected by the radiaiton escaping from the center fo the Milky Way. Significant progress was made through collaborations to investigate the traversal of radiaiton in 3-dimensions in the Galactic Center environment and a publication is planned to be submitted in early 2023. Initial investigations of diffuse interstellar band absorption from dust in the inner Galaxy has been explored using data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey IV (SDSS IV), with plans ot expand this analysis to new observations upcoming in SDSS V.

 

This award also funded the creation of a 7-episode audio course following the Next Generation Science Standards for 5th grade covering astronomy and galaxies. This audio course, produced in collaboration with Tumble Media, is to be released in March 2023 to be used for free around the country, and includes enrichment activities and guided star gazing to be fit into classrooms and homes nationwide. 


Last Modified: 12/28/2022
Modified by: Dhanesh Krishnarao
